title: Assessing the effectiveness of a three-way decision-making framework with multiple features in simulating human judgement of opinion classification
Authors: L.D.C.S. Subhashini, Yuefeng Li, Jinglan Zhang, Ajantha S. Atukorale
Abstract Summary: This study explores a three-way opinion classification (3WOC) model that incorporates semantic and fuzzy features to simulate human judgment in opinion classification. Using an Amazon Musical Instrument dataset and human feedback, the study shows that combining these features enhances classification accuracy and simulates human decision-making better than traditional binary models.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Integration of semantic features and fuzzy features for enhanced opinion classification.
3-Way Feasibility: Demonstrated applicability in opinion mining and customer feedback analysis.
Domains of Application: Opinion mining, sentiment analysis, customer feedback.
Main Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of a three-way decision model compared to binary classification in mimicking human opinion classification.
Evaluation Metrics: Classification coverage, accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, PPV, NPV.
Data Type and Size: Amazon Musical Instrument dataset with 1400 reviews, with a sample of 25 reviews for user testing.
Key Findings: Low statistical correlation between semantic and fuzzy features; 3WOC model outperforms binary classification in simulating human judgments.
Future Work Suggestions: Improve classification summary and adapt the model for broader datasets.
Limitations: Sample limited to university respondents, dataset size restricted.
Keywords: Three-way decision model, opinion mining, fuzzy features, semantic features, human judgment simulation

title: Three-way group decisions using evidence theory under hesitant fuzzy linguistic environment | Scientific Reports
Authors: Chao Zhang, Juanjuan Ding, Deyu Li, Jianming Zhan
Abstract Summary: This study explores multi-granularity three-way decision-making with q-rung orthopair fuzzy sets to handle uncertainty in decision-making. The model integrates multigranulation probabilistic rough sets to support multi-attribute group decision making, exemplified through a corporate financial quality matching case.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Multi-granularity three-way decision models with q-rung orthopair fuzzy sets.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for group decision-making with uncertain and diverse information.
Main Objective: To develop a comprehensive framework using q-rung orthopair fuzzy sets for group decision-making under uncertainty.
Key Findings: The q-ROF MAGDM approach supports flexible decision making by addressing multiple risk levels and reducing classification errors.
Future Work Suggestions: Explore other applications and model extensions.
Keywords: q-rung orthopair fuzzy sets, multi-granularity, three-way decisions, group decision making

title: A three-way decision method with tolerance dominance relations in decision information systems | Artificial Intelligence Review
Authors: Yiyu Yao
Abstract Summary: This paper discusses probabilistic rough sets as a basis for three-way decisions, focusing on how probabilistic three-way decisions can minimize costs associated with classification errors.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Probabilistic rough set models with cost-sensitive classifiers.
3-Way Feasibility: Cost-effective for classification tasks requiring error trade-offs.
Main Objective: To evaluate cost-effective ternary classification versus binary and qualitative three-way models.
Key Findings: Probabilistic three-way decisions reduce misclassification costs.
Future Work Suggestions: Explore further applications in dynamic systems.
Keywords: Probabilistic rough sets, three-way decisions, cost-sensitive classifiers

title: Cost-sensitive three-way email spam filtering | Journal of Intelligent Information Systems
Authors: Guangming Lang, Duoqian Miao, Mingjie Cai
Abstract Summary: Using decision-theoretic rough sets, this study proposes a three-way model to analyze conflicts, providing efficient algorithms to handle dynamic information and support conflict resolution.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Decision-theoretic rough sets for conflict analysis.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for dynamic and complex conflict scenarios.
Main Objective: To develop efficient methods for conflict analysis and dynamic system adaptability.
Key Findings: Three-way models handle conflict dynamics effectively.
Future Work Suggestions: Extend to more real-world conflict cases.
Keywords: Conflict analysis, three-way decisions, decision-theoretic rough sets

title: 3 Decision Table Examples and Use Cases
Authors: Fan Jia, Peide Liu
Abstract Summary: This study combines three-way decisions with multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) using relative and inverse loss functions, proposing a comprehensive approach for investment decision cases.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Three-way decision combined with MCDM, using relative loss functions.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for complex decision problems with multiple criteria.
Main Objective: To extend three-way decisions to MCDM environments.
Key Findings: MCDM-based three-way decisions enhance decision-making flexibility.
Future Work Suggestions: Apply to other multi-criteria contexts.
Keywords: Three-way decisions, multi-criteria decision-making, investment

title: Three-Way Decision for Handling Uncertainty in Machine Learning: A Narrative Review - PMC
Authors: Chao Zhang, Deyu Li, Jiye Liang
Abstract Summary: This paper introduces a multi-granularity three-way decision-making model with interval-valued hesitant fuzzy sets for managing consensus in group decision-making under different risk preferences.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Multi-granularity three-way decisions with interval-valued hesitant fuzzy sets.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for group decisions with varying opinions and risk appetites.
Domains of Application: Group decision making, mergers and acquisitions.
Main Objective: To apply multi-granularity decision-making for diverse group consensus processes.
Data Type and Size: Case study on mergers and acquisitions.
Key Findings: Enhanced group decision-making by addressing consensus and conflicting opinions.
Future Work Suggestions: Explore broader applications in other domains.
Keywords: Multi-granularity, interval-valued hesitant fuzzy, three-way decisions, group consensus

title: RS_3WD.pdf
Authors: Juan Carlos Leyva-López, Eduardo Fernández-González
Abstract Summary: This study extends the ELECTRE III multicriteria outranking methodology for group decision-making, integrating individual preferences to achieve a collective ranking.
3-Way Decision Methodology: ELECTRE III multicriteria outranking and fuzzy binary relation.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for complex group decision-making.
Main Objective: To provide a group decision-making framework combining individual rankings into a collective preference.
Key Findings: ELECTRE III approach was effective for consensus in varied group opinions.
Future Work Suggestions: Further applications in dynamic group settings.
Keywords: Group decision-making, multicriteria analysis, ELECTRE III

title: Granular Computing and Three-way Decisions for Cognitive Analytics | Cognitive Computation
Authors: Dun Liu, Decui Liang, Changchun Wang
Abstract Summary: This model extends three-way decisions to incomplete information systems using interval numbers and hybrid information tables.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Decision-theoretic rough sets with interval numbers.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective in handling missing values and uncertainty.
Main Objective: To adapt three-way decisions for incomplete data.
Key Findings: Effective for decision-making with incomplete data.
Future Work Suggestions: Model optimization for varied domains.
Keywords: Three-way decision, incomplete information, rough sets

title: Decision Trees for Decision-Making
Authors: Huaxiong Li, Libo Zhang, Bing Huang, Xianzhong Zhou
Abstract Summary: This study proposes a three-way decision model for face recognition, focusing on sequential decisions and cost sensitivity.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Sequential three-way decisions with granular computing.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for cases with imbalanced costs.
Main Objective: To optimize face recognition through cost-sensitive, sequential decisions.
Key Findings: Sequential three-way model improves face recognition accuracy.
Future Work Suggestions: Application to other cost-sensitive classification tasks.
Keywords: Three-way decisions, face recognition, cost-sensitive learning

title: A novel three-way decision model under multiple-criteria environment - ScienceDirect
Authors: Jiaxin Zhan, Wenjie Wang, José Carlos R. Alcantud, Jianming Zhan
Abstract Summary: A 3-way decision approach incorporating prospect-regret theory for decision-making in incomplete information systems.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Fuzzy set pair dominance, prospect-regret theory.
3-Way Feasibility: Useful for psychological decision-making processes.
Main Objective: To apply prospect-regret theory to 3WD for realistic decision-making.
Key Findings: Effective in complex decision-making under incomplete information.
Future Work Suggestions: Broaden to more incomplete systems.
Keywords: Three-way decision, prospect theory, regret theory, fuzzy sets

title: Risk Decision Making Based on Decision-theoretic Rough Set: A Three-way View Decision Model: International Journal of Computational Intelligence Systems: Vol 4, No 1
Authors: L.D.C.S. Subhashini, Yuefeng Li, Jinglan Zhang, Ajantha S. Atukorale
Abstract Summary: Examines the integration of fuzzy and semantic features in a 3WOC model for opinion classification, enhancing coverage and accuracy.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Fuzzy and semantic feature integration in 3WOC.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective in simulating human judgment in opinion classification.
Main Objective: To improve opinion classification by integrating multiple feature types.
Key Findings: Combining fuzzy and semantic features improves classification accuracy.
Future Work Suggestions: Extend to diverse datasets.
Keywords: Three-way opinion classification, fuzzy features, semantic features

title: A novel three-way decision model based on incomplete information system - ScienceDirect
Authors: Shikai Li, Xin Long, Yaoyuan Zeng, Xueying Wang
Abstract Summary: The study addresses air target threat assessment using an improved three-way decision model incorporating interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy sets to handle uncertain information and a novel loss function to enhance classification accuracy.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Interval-valued intuitionistic fuzzy sets with attribute dominance-based loss function.
3-Way Feasibility: Useful in real-time military threat assessments with uncertain data.
Domains of Application: Military defense, air target threat classification.
Main Objective: To improve classification accuracy and decision-making reliability in air target threat assessment.
Evaluation Metrics: Classification accuracy, robustness in uncertain scenarios.
Key Findings: Improved threat classification capability in uncertain conditions.
Future Work Suggestions: Expand to broader military applications.
Keywords: Three-way decisions, interval-valued fuzzy sets, threat classification, military decision support

title: Three-Way Decisions and Cognitive Computing | Cognitive Computation
Authors: Yufei Chen, Xiaodong Yue, Hamido Fujita, Siyuan Fu
Abstract Summary: This paper proposes a three-way decision model for diagnosing focal liver lesions (FLL) in CT images, balancing automatic classification and expert review for uncertain cases.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Decision-theoretic rough sets for tri-partitioning FLL diagnoses.
3-Way Feasibility: Applicable in medical diagnostics where uncertainty needs expert confirmation.
Main Objective: To integrate automated decision support with human judgment in FLL diagnostics.
Key Findings: Effective at distinguishing between benign and malignant liver lesions.
Future Work Suggestions: Broader applications in complex medical diagnostics.
Limitations: Requires high-quality CT data for accuracy.
Keywords: Three-way decision, focal liver lesions, decision support, CT imaging

title: Three-way decision approaches to conflict analysis using decision-theoretic rough set theory - ScienceDirect
Authors: Yusheng Li, Feng Gao, Mengyi Sha, Xueyan Shao
Abstract Summary: Introduces a sequential three-way decision model with threshold learning for credit risk prediction, using loan-specific thresholds based on loss and information gain.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Sequential three-way decisions with dynamic threshold learning.
3-Way Feasibility: Adaptable to real-time financial credit risk scenarios.
Main Objective: To optimize credit risk classification with individual thresholds for each loan.
Key Findings: Reduces credit risk classification errors and cost.
Future Work Suggestions: Extend to different financial datasets.
Limitations: Specific to datasets with detailed loan attributes.
Keywords: Three-way decisions, credit risk prediction, threshold learning, financial decision support

title: Three-way decision support for diagnosis on focal liver lesions - ScienceDirect
Authors: Andrea Campagner, Federico Cabitza, Davide Ciucci
Abstract Summary: This narrative review highlights the application of three-way decisions to manage input and output uncertainties in machine learning, discussing cases in ML training and prediction.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Trisecting-acting-outcome (TAO) framework applied to machine learning uncertainty.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective in ML scenarios requiring abstention or uncertainty management.
Main Objective: To assess three-way decision applications in uncertainty within ML.
Key Findings: Highlights strengths of TWD in managing ML uncertainties.
Future Work Suggestions: Explore practical applications in various ML domains.
Limitations: Lacks empirical data for ML model impact.
Keywords: Three-way decisions, machine learning, uncertainty, TAO model

title: Sequential three-way decision and granulation for cost-sensitive face recognition - ScienceDirect
Authors: Jianhua Dai, Tao Chen, Kai Zhang, Dun Liu, Weiping Ding
Abstract Summary: This paper proposes a three-way decision model incorporating prospect theory and fuzzy sets, enabling risk-sensitive decision-making in multi-attribute scenarios.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Prospect theory-based fuzzy three-way decisions with recursive trisecting.
3-Way Feasibility: Useful in high-risk environments requiring sensitivity to user preferences.
Main Objective: To integrate risk-sensitive and fuzzy logic into three-way decision-making.
Evaluation Metrics: Effectiveness index based on fuzzy set attributes.
Key Findings: Improves decision accuracy by incorporating risk attitudes.
Future Work Suggestions: Apply to diverse decision-making scenarios.
Keywords: Prospect theory, three-way decisions, fuzzy logic, risk-sensitive decisions

title: Interval-valued hesitant fuzzy multi-granularity three-way decisions in consensus processes with applications to multi-attribute group decision making - ScienceDirect
Authors: JingTao Yao, Yiyu Yao, Davide Ciucci, Kaizhu Huang
Abstract Summary: This paper explores how granular computing and three-way decisions support cognitive analytics. It addresses the theoretical and application aspects of cognitive computing, showcasing three-way decision models and their use in diverse fields such as business, management, and medical sciences.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Granular computing with multi-granular and triadic approaches for three-way decisions.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective in fields requiring data abstraction and multi-level reasoning.
Domains of Application: Cognitive computing, data mining, artificial intelligence.
Main Objective: To integrate granular and three-way computing for cognitive analytics.
Key Findings: Cognitive analytics is enhanced through tri-partition-based decision-making.
Future Work Suggestions: Extend models to dynamic, real-time applications.
Keywords: Cognitive analytics, granular computing, three-way decisions, tri-partition

title: A three-way decision approach with prospect-regret theory via fuzzy set pair dominance degrees for incomplete information systems - ScienceDirect
Authors: Yiyu Yao
Abstract Summary: This foundational paper describes the application of rough set theory to three-way decision-making. It introduces a trisecting-and-acting framework, using rough set approximations for categorization in probabilistic rough sets.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Rough set theory with trisecting and acting framework.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for uncertain classification in rough set-based systems.
Main Objective: To formalize three-way decisions through rough sets.
Key Findings: Rough set-based three-way decision models enhance decision-making flexibility.
Future Work Suggestions: Develop practical applications in decision support.
Keywords: Rough sets, three-way decisions, probabilistic rough sets, trisecting

title: A novel multi-granularity three-way decision making approach in q-rung orthopair fuzzy information systems - ScienceDirect
Authors: Wenjie Wang, Jianming Zhan, Weiping Ding, Shuping Wan
Abstract Summary: This paper discusses a three-way decision model utilizing tolerance dominance relations in ordered decision information systems for medical diagnoses. It applies the model to classify patient data in a multi-attribute environment, enhancing decision accuracy by balancing loss and gain functions.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Tolerance dominance relations in ordered decision systems.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for MADM scenarios, particularly in medical diagnosis.
Main Objective: To enhance patient classification accuracy by integrating tolerance dominance.
Key Findings: Improves patient classification with reduced decision risks.
Future Work Suggestions: Broaden to other medical diagnostic datasets.
Keywords: Tolerance dominance, three-way decisions, medical diagnostics, multi-attribute

title: Hyperautomation for Air Quality Evaluations: A Perspective of Evidential Three-way Decision-making | Cognitive Computation
Authors: Bing Zhou, Yiyu Yao, Jigang Luo
Abstract Summary: This paper presents a cost-sensitive three-way decision model for email spam filtering. By calculating thresholds based on decision-theoretic rough sets, the model enhances the classification accuracy and reduces misclassification costs.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Decision-theoretic rough sets with cost-sensitive thresholds.
3-Way Feasibility: Useful for systems requiring sensitivity to misclassification costs.
Main Objective: To improve spam filtering by incorporating cost-sensitive classification.
Key Findings: Reduces misclassification in spam filtering through deferment decisions.
Future Work Suggestions: Apply to other classification tasks with cost considerations.
Keywords: Cost-sensitive learning, three-way decisions, email spam filtering, rough sets

title: A method of choosing multiway partitions for classification and decision trees: Journal of Applied Statistics: Vol 18, No 1
Authors: Yiyu Yao
Abstract Summary: This paper introduces the trisecting-and-acting model in cognitive computing. It examines how three-way decisions mirror human cognitive processes and discusses the cognitive benefits of this approach.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Trisecting-and-acting model with cognitive computing focus.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for applications mirroring human cognitive processes.
Main Objective: To formalize three-way decision approaches in cognitive computing.
Key Findings: Highlights cognitive advantages of three-way decision models.
Future Work Suggestions: Apply to cognitive systems in artificial intelligence.
Keywords: Cognitive computing, three-way decisions, trisecting-and-acting, decision support

title: A new method for group decision support based on ELECTRE III methodology - ScienceDirect
Authors: Jiajia Zhou, Yian Zhu, Lian Li
Abstract Summary: This study proposes a Pythagorean fuzzy TOPSIS model for node importance evaluation in Internet of Drones (IoD) networks. The model integrates multi-attribute assessments with a 3-way decision framework, using Pythagorean fuzzy middle ideal solutions for decision-making in UAV swarm networks.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Pythagorean fuzzy TOPSIS model with middle ideal solutions.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for multi-attribute assessments in dynamic networks.
Main Objective: To improve UAV node importance evaluation for enhanced network security.
Evaluation Metrics: Node importance, robustness to network changes.
Key Findings: Provides a robust assessment of node importance, enhancing security in UAV networks.
Future Work Suggestions: Explore other network types and multi-attribute frameworks.
Limitations: Limited to UAV networks with specific node measures.
Keywords: Pythagorean fuzzy sets, three-way decisions, UAV networks, node importance

title: The superiority of three-way decisions in probabilistic rough set models - ScienceDirect
Authors: Wenke Ding, Xingchen Li, Xiajiong Shen
Abstract Summary: This paper introduces a 3-way decision model under a hesitant fuzzy linguistic environment using Dempster-Shafer theory to fuse information. The model evaluates alternatives in a hesitant fuzzy multi-attribute group decision-making (MAGDM) setup, accounting for confidence and loss in group evaluations.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Hesitant fuzzy linguistic 3-way decisions with evidence theory.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for MAGDM scenarios involving hesitancy in linguistic evaluations.
Main Objective: To enhance decision fusion under uncertain linguistic data.
Key Findings: Improves precision in group decision-making by reducing information loss.
Future Work Suggestions: Apply to broader hesitant linguistic systems.
Limitations: Complexity in integrating multiple hesitant fuzzy terms.
Keywords: Hesitant fuzzy linguistic, 3-way decisions, Dempster-Shafer theory, MAGDM

title: A three-phase model of retirement decision making.
Authors: Jie Shi, Qiupeng Liu, Chunlei Shi, Mingming Lv, Wenli Pang
Abstract Summary: This study develops an intuitionistic fuzzy sequential three-way decision model for decision-making under incomplete information systems, employing a density-based granulation method and enhanced decision processes for multi-level granularity.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Intuitionistic fuzzy sequential 3-way decision model.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective in handling incomplete data in multi-granularity decision-making.
Main Objective: To manage decision accuracy in uncertain environments through granulation.
Key Findings: Improved handling of incomplete data and accuracy.

Keywords: Intuitionistic fuzzy sets, three-way decisions, sequential model, incomplete information

title: Sequential three-way decision with automatic threshold learning for credit risk prediction
Authors: Bao Qing Hu
Abstract Summary: This paper establishes a framework for three-way decisions based on three elements: decision measurement, condition, and evaluation function. The study presents the concepts of three-way decision spaces and their applications to fuzzy and rough set-based decisions, introducing multi-granulation methods.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Multi-granulation three-way decision space based on fuzzy and rough sets.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for systems requiring flexible decision spaces and multi-granular analysis.
Main Objective: To create flexible decision spaces by integrating fuzzy and rough sets.
Key Findings: Establishes a theoretical basis for multi-granulation decision-making.
Future Work Suggestions: Extend to practical decision support applications.
Keywords: Three-way decisions, fuzzy sets, rough sets, multi-granulation

title: Three-way decisions with Pythagorean fuzzy TOPSIS for Internet of Drones
Authors: Yiding Wang, Junsheng Qiao, Tengbiao Li
Abstract Summary: This research proposes fuzzy implication-based methods to transform semi-three-way decision spaces into full three-way decision spaces, enhancing decision-making effectiveness. The study includes comparisons to existing fuzzy logic methods, with results showing improved anti-noise capabilities.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Transformation from semi-three-way to full three-way decision spaces using fuzzy implications.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for complex environments where decision accuracy is critical.
Main Objective: To improve decision robustness and accuracy in semi-three-way spaces.
Key Findings: Improved robustness against noise and higher decision precision.
Future Work Suggestions: Apply to broader decision-making scenarios.
Keywords: Fuzzy implications, three-way decisions, semi-three-way decision spaces

title: Fused Decision Rules of Multi-Intuitionistic Fuzzy Information Systems Based on the D-S Evidence Theory and Three-Way Decisions
Authors: Stefania Boffa, Davide Ciucci
Abstract Summary: This article explores a linguistic approach to three-way decisions using evaluative expressions like 'small,' 'medium,' and 'big.' It aims to make three-way decision outcomes more understandable for non-technical users, aligning with goals of Explainable AI.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Evaluative linguistic expressions in three-way decision regions.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective in scenarios requiring user-friendly, explainable decisions.
Main Objective: To enhance interpretability of three-way decisions for non-technical users.
Key Findings: Increases decision transparency for non-technical users.
Future Work Suggestions: Broaden applications to other explainable AI tasks.
Keywords: Evaluative linguistic expressions, explainable AI, three-way decisions, natural language

title: Three-way decisions based multi-attribute decision-making with utility and loss functions
Authors: Changlin Xu, Songqian Mao
Abstract Summary: This paper presents a three-way decision approach for incomplete information systems using interval loss functions to reduce decision-making errors. The methodology uses granulation and interval aggregation techniques.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Interval loss function-based aggregation for incomplete information.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective in settings with incomplete data.
Main Objective: To mitigate errors in decision-making with incomplete information.
Key Findings: Reduces decision-making errors under uncertainty.
Future Work Suggestions: Extend to larger-scale systems.
Keywords: Incomplete information, interval loss function, three-way decisions, aggregation

title: Intuitionistic Fuzzy Sequential Three-Way Decision Model in Incomplete Information Systems
Authors: Jie Yang, Xiaoqi Wang, Guoyin Wang, Qinghua Zhang, Nenggan Zheng, Di Wu
Abstract Summary: This study introduces a fuzziness-based three-way decision model under a shadowed sets framework, aimed at minimizing misclassification by optimizing threshold parameters. The model uses neighborhood rough sets and shadowed set frameworks to improve decision consistency.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Fuzziness-based neighborhood rough sets in shadowed sets framework.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for high-stakes environments requiring precise thresholds.
Main Objective: To enhance decision accuracy by optimizing threshold parameters.
Key Findings: Achieves lower misclassification rates with optimized thresholding.
Future Work Suggestions: Explore other granulation methods.
Keywords: Neighborhood rough sets, shadowed sets, fuzziness, three-way decisions

title: Target Threat Level Classification Based on Improved Three-way Decisions
Authors: Zhihua Zhang, Lu Liu, Chunying Zhang, Jing Ren, Jiang Ma, Liya Wang, Bin Liu
Abstract Summary: This study presents a moving target evolutionary game defense model (MTTEGDM) for cyberspace security using three-way decisions. The model introduces dynamic weight adjustments and integrates attack intentions to enhance defense accuracy. Simulations demonstrate its efficacy in predicting optimal defense strategies.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Three-way evolutionary game model with dynamic weight adjustments.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for dynamic, uncertain cyber environments.

title: GIFTWD: A Prospect Theory-Based Generalized Intuitionistic Fuzzy Three-Way Decision Model
Authors: Yusheng Li, Mengyi Sha
Abstract Summary: This paper proposes a two-stage framework for credit risk prediction that leverages three-way decisions and particle swarm optimization to optimize threshold learning. The approach aims to enhance prediction by delaying decisions for records requiring more data.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Two-stage framework with three-way decisions and automatic threshold learning.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for managing delayed decisions in financial risk predictions.
Main Objective: To improve credit risk classification accuracy with three-way decisions.
Data Type and Size: Financial dataset from a Chinese bank.
Key Findings: Reduced error in credit risk predictions with delayed decisions.
Future Work Suggestions: Broaden to other financial datasets.
Keywords: Credit risk, three-way decisions, threshold learning, particle swarm optimization

title: Hexagons of Opposition in Linguistic Three-Way Decisions
Authors: Hongwu Qin, Yanyan Han, Xiuqin Ma
Abstract Summary: This paper presents a multi-attribute decision approach under interval-valued fuzzy soft sets, leveraging ideal solutions within a three-way decision framework. Applications in emergency decision-making demonstrate improved classification of decision alternatives.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Interval-valued fuzzy soft sets in multi-attribute decision-making.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective in multi-criteria decision contexts with uncertain data.
Main Objective: To enhance multi-criteria decision analysis under uncertain conditions.

Keywords: Interval-valued fuzzy sets, multi-attribute decision-making, three-way decisions, emergency decision

title: Fuzzy implications-based transformation approaches from semi-three-way decision spaces to three-way decision spaces and their applications
Authors: Can Pan, Liangxiao Jiang, Chaoqun Li
Abstract Summary: This paper introduces a three-way decision-based label integration (TDLI) model for crowdsourcing. The model groups instances based on label quality into three subsets for customized label integration, which enhances labeling accuracy.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Label integration with three-way decisions for high, medium, and low label quality instances.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for managing uncertain labels in crowdsourced data.
Main Objective: To improve label integration accuracy using three-way decision partitions.

title: Three-Way Decisions with Evaluative Linguistic Expressions
Authors: Jianfeng Xu, Ruihua Wang, Yuanjian Zhang, Weiping Ding
Abstract Summary: This paper develops an adaptive sequential three-way decision (AS3-DTW) model for dynamic time warping in time-series data, enhancing computational efficiency by adjusting search spaces based on three-way decisions.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Sequential three-way decisions with granularity adjustments for dynamic time warping.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for high-dimensional time-series data.

title: Three-Way Decision-Making Based on Incomplete Information System and Its Application
Authors: Benwei Chen, Xianyong Zhang, Zhiying Lv
Abstract Summary: This study introduces S-type preference measures for interval-valued systems, enhancing three-way decision models. It proposes three-level dominance relations, which allow systematic three-way decision (3WD) models for sorting and classification. Simulations validate the S-type measure’s effectiveness.
3-Way Decision Methodology: S-type preference measure for interval-valued dominance relations.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for uncertain, interval-valued datasets.
Main Objective: To improve classification accuracy in interval-valued systems.
Key Findings: Enhanced decision performance over existing models.
Future Work Suggestions: Extend to real-time decision systems.

title: Fuzziness-Based Three-Way Decision With Neighborhood Rough Sets Under the Framework of Shadowed Sets
Authors: Jiaxin Song, Haidong Zhang
Abstract Summary: Integrating set pair analysis with regret theory, this paper proposes a three-way decision model under incomplete information scenarios. It introduces an entropy-based method for attribute weighting and utilizes regret theory to calculate relative utilities.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Set pair analysis combined with regret theory.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for multi-attribute decision-making under incomplete data.
Main Objective: To address incomplete information in decision-making.
Key Findings: Improved decision precision using set pair analysis.
Future Work Suggestions: Test on larger real-world datasets.
Keywords: Set pair analysis, regret theory, three-way decisions

title: Three-way decisions space and three-way decisions
Authors: Xiaozhi Chen, Ligeng Zou
Abstract Summary: This study introduces three-way decision models grounded in ideal relations to support multi-attribute decision-making. The models employ superiority and inferiority criteria, integrating decision-theoretic rough sets.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Ideal relations using decision-theoretic rough sets.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for decisions with ranked alternatives.
Main Objective: To optimize ranking in multi-attribute decisions.
Key Findings: Enhanced ranking for complex decisions.
Future Work Suggestions: Extend ideal relations to additional decision contexts.
Keywords: Multi-attribute decision-making, three-way decisions, ideal relations

title: A three-way decision method based on COPRAS in the weak probabilistic linguistic term set information systems
Authors: Yong Liu, Xue-ge Guo, Qin Jiang, Jia-qi An
Journal/Conference: Research Article on Grey Decision Analysis
Abstract Summary: Proposes a dynamic three-way decision model using grey relational analysis, suitable for systems with changing decision objects. The model is tested with case studies on dynamic environments.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Grey relational analysis with dynamic update rules.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for dynamic environments with evolving data.
Main Objective: To adapt decision rules to evolving data.
Key Findings: Effective decision-making in dynamic environments.

title: Two new kinds of protoconcepts based on three-way decisions model
Authors: Tengbiao Li, Junsheng Qiao
Abstract Summary: Introduces a MAGDM model for healthcare waste management using q-rung orthopair fuzzy sets within a three-way decision framework.
3-Way Decision Methodology: q-Rung orthopair fuzzy sets in multi-attribute decision-making.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for uncertain healthcare management decisions.

title: Two‐stage credit risk prediction framework based on three‐way decisions with automatic threshold learning
Authors: Benwei Chen, Xianyong Zhang, Zhiying Lv
Abstract Summary: This study introduces S-type preference measures for interval-valued systems, enhancing three-way decision models. It proposes three-level dominance relations, which allow systematic three-way decision (3WD) models for sorting and classification. Simulations validate the S-type measure’s effectiveness.
3-Way Decision Methodology: S-type preference measure for interval-valued dominance relations.
3-Way Feasibility: Suitable for uncertain, interval-valued datasets.
Main Objective: To improve classification accuracy in interval-valued systems.
Key Findings: Enhanced decision performance over existing models.
Future Work Suggestions: Extend to real-time decision systems.
Keywords: Interval-valued systems, three-way decisions, preference measures

title: Multi-Attribute Three-Way Decision Approach Based on Ideal Solutions under Interval-Valued Fuzzy Soft Environment
Authors: Jiaxin Song, Haidong Zhang
Abstract Summary: Integrating set pair analysis with regret theory, this paper proposes a three-way decision model under incomplete information scenarios. It introduces an entropy-based method for attribute weighting and utilizes regret theory to calculate relative utilities.
3-Way Decision Methodology: Set pair analysis combined with regret theory.
3-Way Feasibility: Effective for multi-attribute decision-making under incomplete data.
Main Objective: To address incomplete information in decision-making.
Key Findings: Improved decision precision using set pair analysis.
Future Work Suggestions: Test on larger real-world datasets.
Keywords: Set pair analysis, regret theory, three-way decisions

Predictors of hurricane evacuation decisions: A meta-analysis
Abstract Summary: Synthesizes data from 33 models to identify key predictors of hurricane evacuation decisions.
Main Objective: To estimate effect sizes of predictors influencing evacuation decisions.
Key Findings: Evacuation orders and having plans are strong predictors.
Future Work Suggestions: Improve modeling of socioeconomic barriers.
Keywords: meta-analysis, evacuation decisions, hurricanes

title: Analyzing Risk Perception, Evacuation Decision and Delay Time: A Case Study of the 2021 Marshall Fire in Colorado
Understanding the Decision-Making Process for Hurricane Evacuation Orders: A Case Study of Florida County Emergency Managers
Abstract Summary: Analyzes fixed and random factors influencing emergency managers' hurricane evacuation decisions.
Main Objective: To understand the interplay of factors affecting evacuation orders.
Key Findings: Uncertainty and collaboration are critical in decision-making.
Future Work Suggestions: Expand research to other regions and contexts.
Keywords: hurricane evacuation, emergency management, bounded rationality

title: Why They Escape: Mining Prioritized Fuzzy Decision Rule in Crowd Evacuation
Journal/Conference: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
Abstract Summary: Explores how socioeconomic conditions and proximity to hazards affect flood evacuation decisions.
Main Objective: To model evacuation decisions using prioritized fuzzy rules.
Key Findings: Herding behavior and spatial factors play crucial roles.
Future Work Suggestions: Extend to real-time prediction applications.
Keywords: crowd evacuation, fuzzy decision rules, genetic fuzzy system

title: Evacuation decision making and risk perception: flooded rural communities in Pakistan
Abstract Summary: Proposes a coevolutionary fuzzy rule miner for predicting crowd evacuation behavior and interpreting decision-making.
Main Objective: To assess factors influencing evacuation decisions in flood-prone rural areas.
Key Findings: Fear and proximity to hazards significantly affect willingness to evacuate.
Future Work Suggestions: Implement educational campaigns for risk awareness.
Keywords: flood risk, evacuation decisions, rural communities

title: A Model for Making Dynamic Collective Decisions in Emergency Evacuation Tasks in Fuzzy Conditions
Modeling Evacuation Decisions in the 2019 Kincade fire in California
Abstract Summary: Analyzes fixed and random factors influencing emergency managers' hurricane evacuation decisions.
Main Objective: To understand how sociodemographics and risk perception influence evacuation decisions.
Data Type and Size: Survey data from Sonoma County, California
Key Findings: Household composition, income, and evacuation orders are key predictors.
Future Work Suggestions: Develop generalized models for broader applicability.
Limitations: Focus on a single wildfire event.
Keywords: wildfires, evacuation decisions, risk perception

title: Evacuation Decisions during the Great East Japan Earthquake
Abstract Summary: Synthesizes data from 33 models to identify key predictors of hurricane evacuation decisions.
Main Objective: To assess how tsunami warnings and social behavior influenced evacuation outcomes.
Key Findings: Delayed warnings reduce evacuation rates by 3% per minute of delay.
Future Work Suggestions: Incorporate real-time behavioral data.
Limitations: Focused on a single event and specific regional data.
Keywords: evacuation decisions, tsunami warnings, field effects
